New Records: Anthony Volpe hit a grand slam in the third inning, and the Yankees added six runs against the Dodgers' bullpen, marking the first time they've won a game in this postseason by more than three runs.
Key Match Events: Freddie Freeman hit a home run to give the Dodgers a lead, but the Yankees responded with a four-run third inning to take a 5-2 advantage.
Brent Honeywell gave up five runs in the eighth and turned the game into a blowout.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers were expected to turn to their high-leverage relievers if they held a lead, but their plan was to conserve them after using six of them in the prior night's game.
Post-Match Reflections: The Yankees' victory gives them a chance to force a Game 6, as no team that trailed 3-0 in the World Series has ever come back to win.
Aaron Judge's eighth-inning RBI single was a good sign for the Yankees.
Volpe's all-around performance could portend the sort of lineup depth the Yankees need.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers will have all of their high-leverage arms ready for Game 5, except maybe Daniel Hudson.
The Yankees' ace, Gerrit Cole, will start Game 5 after an excellent showing in Game 1.
Others: The game was a turning point for the Yankees, who finally showed up and blasted three home runs, including Volpe's grand slam.
The Dodgers' attempt at winning the World Series with a bullpen game went awry.
